In Problem 3.1, we looked for a pattern that relates the two variables, and then we described the pattern in words and then equations.

For example,

The total amount of money collected is 350 times the number of people.

total amount of money collected = 350 • number of people

↓ ↓

T n

T = 350 • n

Note on Notation: When we multiply a number by a letter variable, we can leave out the multiplication sign. So 350n means 350 × n or 350 • n. We can shorten the equation even more:

T = 350n

Expression

T and 350n

T and 350n are both expressions for the total amount of money collected from n people.

The coefficient is 350. A coefficient is the number that you multiply by a variable.

Equation

T = 350n

This equation shows that the two expressions for the total amount of money are equal.

The equation is another way to represent the relationship between the two variables, T and n.
In this problem, we will continue to look at situations that involve one operation.
